ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course allowed me to gain insights into the basic background of important issues currently faced by leaders and countries in the global arena ranging from Great Power competition, climate change, authoritarianism, disinformation and issues facing developing nations such as Africa, Eastern Europe.
I learned very broadly about a number of different global issues.
I developed a general understanding of a variety of issues related to international relations and global politics.

This course provided a broad overview of different parts of the world (with a particular emphasis on the Middle East) and various important topics to consider for those considering to major in international relations (e.g., climate change, education, disinformation, etc.).
world knowledge
I gained a baseline understanding of the global affairs topic and current events around the globe.

I learned about the state of global affairs and current events on the global stage. It was an engaging class that covered many interesting topics and I loved the guest speakers. I improved my essay writing skills, discussion participation, and presentation abilities.
gained basic understanding of many global events
Overall understanding of US influence in the world

This course covered a large variety of topics, so I felt that I did not learn in-depth about topics that I already knew a bit about but rather was exposed to many current events and issues that I had not considered before.

Before taking this course I had no knowledge on the information taught. I felt this class was extremely interesting and much needed for the future of our generation. I thoroughly enjoyed this class throughout this whole semester.
I learned how to situate various global events in the context of current and historical events. I learned how to take effective notes during lectures to expand my understanding of global affairs.
i learned a lot about international relations
I was able to understand how Americans view the world and a better insight into US foreign policy.

I gained public speaking skills in the section of this course as we had to express our ideas and opinions regarding the topics presented in the lectures. I also gained teamwork and writing skills because of the assigned projects and essays.
Learned a lot about current events, foreign policy issues.
I learned about global affairs, US and Chinese power competition, climate change and some of the key issues facing politics right now.
I learned a lot about a wide range of topics from around the world.
I gained a thorough overview of international issues by region and field, as well as tools to assess 21st century US foreign policy.
I learned how to take good notes from a lecture style class and then be able to gather my own thoughts from them.
I developed a basic knowledge of global affairs across a variety of subjects, from the Middle East to climate change. I learned how to effectively lead a discussion on current events.
Knowledge about current events and information about the greater global affairs community, the history behind current global trends, and solutions on how to fix current issues.
The beginning of this course was a good survey of current geopolitical affairs. It focused primarily on the Middle East  which is Emma Sky's expertise.
I learned how the Global Affairs major is structure and also the workings of international organizations.
Extensive knowledge on global issue and solutions.
international problems, relations and wars that has and still have a big impact on the world
I was introduced to a variety of topics and conflicts that affect our world today.

My knowledge of the role of international multilateral organizations in governing the world increased dramatically. My understanding of US international relations more generally is greater now than it was before taking this class.
I develop knowledge about different issues across the globe and different perspectives on these issues from the Yale Fellows.
I learned valuable techniques for approaching international issues, as well as writing techniques for argumentative essays.

This course was a survey of geopolitics and global problems. I learned about China, Russia, the EU, climate change, and modern technologies from excellent guest speakers. I also learned how to write a policy memo and papers on international relations. These skills will help me in Global Affairs courses moving forward.
Worldwide overall knowledge and the factors that affect it. The great questions of the world and how we can begin to answer them.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The repertoire of speakers that were invited to speak to the students was of the very highest of standards and allowed students to gain deep insights into key issues and challenges faced by global leaders.

Strenghts: interesting lectures and readings, light work load
Weaknesses: Some topics gone through on a surface level as with one lecture can not get into depth.

GLBL 101 benefits from featuring World Fellows as guest lecturers. Consequently, the range of material that we cover is broader and more comprehensively, with concrete, real-world examples used to contextualize the topics covered in class.

The guest lecturers are both the strength and weakness of this course. While they are all quite accomplished and have very interesting backgrounds in the context of IR, some are more able to give engaging hour-long lectures than others. I also learned a lot about many global affairs topics I didn't know too much, if anything, about. At the same time, given the nature of the intro course, it was a bit unfortunate to not discuss them in any depth.
nice
The course does a great job of having students gain a diverse understanding of the global affairs topic by focusing on historic and current events from around the world.
I appreciated hearing from guest speakers, as it made the class engaging and relevant. I have no suggestions for improvement of this course.
some weeks lectures were very interesting however other weeks could be very boring

Strengths: Sky's lectures, the readings, and section were all very interesting
Weaknesses: Many of the Yale World Fellows lectures were disorganized and hard to follow, overall class engagement was low

The strengths of this course are that it allows for students to sample different topics. This comes with a downside, there are some lectures that I was not at all engaged with and lacked the motivation to attend.

This class has tons of critical information that needs to be addressed to all students throughout Yale. It was very interesting throughout the whole semester learning about the past and present affairs that go on throughout the world.

Not many weaknesses for this course, although if you have no background on any of this information you will need to do a lot of reading and research to truly understand the topics that are talked about and addressed in this course throughout the semester.
I think this was an amazing course and I have no recommendations to improve it.
great lectures but be tu broad topics for the final papers
The strength of this course was the level of expertise of the guest lecturers. A weakness, however, was that the class had a US centric nature which became quite repetitive and annoying.

I enjoyed this course since a variety of topics and world problems were addressed and as such, I briefly learned about a wide range of topics, which allowed me to develop an interest in new areas. 

However, I believe that a weakness in this course was the disparity in terms of quality between the different lectures. While some lectures were very interesting and well planned, others were unorganized and monotonous. Thus, the class really depended on the lecturer and their commitment to a good, interactive presentation.
Engagement within discussion was a strength; guest speakers were great.
The course was very surface-level at times, but it gave a nice overview of some of the key global affairs issues of our time.
Very insightful and interesting class. Real world problems that kept the class interested

I think the course should do a better job of going into more detail about each topic, or perhaps even focusing on fewer so that certain ones can be further explored. 
I enjoyed how the course had many expert speakers on the topics come and teach classes.

The best thing about the course was the great number of skillful and engaging guest lecturers. The course could be improved by adding a bit more theory on international relations, as well as encouraging more fruitful debates on modern-day issues in class or section.

The strengths are certainly the lecturers as they are very interesting and come from a breadth of topics. The weaknesses were that some of the lectures seemed to end before the full time of the class and then seemed to just fill time until the end of class.

The strength of this course is its diversity in topics and speakers. It was a unique experience to have a different speaker each lecture to give a unique perspective on global events. I think the course could be improved by posting the speakers presentations on canvas after their lecture to make it easier to use their information for the midterm/final papers.

Strengths - The lecturers were on some occasions amazing! A former Governor, a current Ambassador, a human rights lawyer, etc. There were brilliant insights during each lecture. The professor is also very knowledgeable and a valuable asset, which is why it was sad to see such little involvement with the course towards the middle/end. 

Weaknesses - By far, the disorganization of the course hurt it the most. It was frustrating to be given an assignment with little to no guidance on what the professor/TA was looking for, and I think the course suffered from a lack of engagement because of this. Second, the lectures and readings were, by and large, optionalvery little of the information presented in either of these were necessary to complete the assignments and because of that, the class felt like an option to attend. Regardless of how interesting the material is, if its not immediately pertinent to the required assignments, its hard to justify attendance. Toward the end of the course, when workload from other courses started adding up, I started attending lectures and doing readings less and less, unless I knew the speaker was notable or the material was necessary for research we had to conduct.

The second half of this course was a waste of time. The lectures were hard to follow and did not come together to show any sort of trend or overall big picture of the current state of the world. The first lectures were fascinating, but the second half of the semester did not make the course worthwhile.

Strengths: some of the guest lecturers are fantastic and present interesting content from around the world, my teaching fellow was very knowledgeable and always willing to talk about his experience, we covered a few topics in depth like great power competition. Weaknesses: the class seemed a bit disorganized and sometimes the lectures did not quite line up with the syllabus, by the second half of the semester much less than half the class showed up to lecture and engagement was low. I wish we would have covered in section how to write a policy memo before being asked to write one for the midterm.
It was interesting to have a bunch of different speakers however i think the lectures could be a bit long sometimes.
The class should be more engaging and focus less on western perspectives.
More organized with office hours.

Strengths - Provides an overview of a good multitude of topics. Sections moderated by insightful TFs provide a great venue for fruitful discussion.
Weaknesses - Felt that a lot of those topics were approached from a very US-centric perspective - not enough emphasis, I don't think, on the perspectives of other agents, such as multilaterals.

This course was amazing, as it engaged students via the caliber of lecturers and its topics. This was an introductory global affairs course, and it accomplished its goal of getting students excited to take on the world in their studies in the future.

A fine survey course for dipping your toes in the water of Global Affairs. If you are knowledgeable generally about current events across the globe you won't gain too much insight. Solid course if you aren't.

I really liked how the course had a different speaker every lecture, I thought that was a very interesting system. I do think however, that we could have had more engagement with professor Sky herself. Also, I don't know if this is simply because I enjoyed them, but the sections seemed to go by really quickly.

The strengths of this course include sections being ran incredibly well. Also, section leaders were always extremely helpful with any questions about the course. One weakness I found was with so few assignments, it is hard to show gradual improvement in the course.

Strengths: excellent guest speakers, flexible assignments that allow students to explore areas they are interested in, class organization, 
Weaknesses: Because every lecture focuses on a new topic, students do not learn about any one topic in-depth.

Strengths - Interesting and relevant information, lecture style by multiple speakers, powerful discussions in section
Weakness - Possibly individual speakers with topics that do not fit greater theme of the class. Required readings missing the idea of lecture

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This course was not very engaging. If you are looking for an engaging course in Global Affairs I would not take this class.

Yes, I would very much recommend this course to all Yale College students and even to students from the graduate schools as having a good foundation in global affairs is very helpful when developing other skill-sets in areas of business, environmental sciences and other social sciences such as economics and sociology.
Yes! It is a great course as an intro to Global Affairs. The course covers many interesting and essential global topics.
I would. It is a fun and relaxed class that also informs you on current events.

No. If you are someone that is not very familiar with global trends and politics, this is probably a good course for you. Otherwise, its a waste of your time. Much of the stuff we learned was extremely surface level, which made lectures quite tedious. Guest lecturers started out very strong early in the year but gradually got very hit or miss later on in the semester. There was really no reason to go to lecture at all because you didn't need the information presented in the lecture to do well on the midterm and final assignments. This class is the definition of a gut, but left me very disinterested as a poly sci major.
This course is a wonderful addition to the repertoire of any prospective Global Affairs/Political Science major.

If the student is interested in IR, it could be a relatively low-work course to get a basic level of understanding on different topics and to listen to prominent speakers. That being said, lectures can be relatively dull depending on the day/topic/speaker, but if you are really interested in learning more about IR and a wide range of topics, then I would recommend it.
absolutely
Yes, this is a great class to take if you're looking for low stress and learning the basics of global affairs.
I would recommend this course to another student. It is important to learn about global affairs, and the guest speakers and interesting topics make the class very appealing.
yes if youre interested in learning briefly about many global events without a high workload
Yes, especially if you're looking for an introduction to various global affairs topics with a light workload. Three papers and a presentation, but otherwise no work
Yes, the quality of lectures and content dropped after midterms, but it was still a very useful introduction to global affairs.
If a student is unsure about what topic to focus on within the umbrella of politics and history, I would definitely recommend this course.

Yes, absolutely recommend this course to individuals with intermediate knowledge of global affairs. You will learn a lot of the current issues and past issues that are present throughout the world in this course.

I would highly recommend this course because it was extremely interesting. You have the opportunity to further explore global events and issues while learning and interacting with experts in the field. Absolutely loved this class and the material.
yes it was so interesting to hear from so many people
I would not recommend this course to another student because of the clear US centric nature of the course.

I would recommend this course to another student in order to learn about a variety of topics regarding world issues in one course. However, I would warn them that the quality of each lecture will vary. It is also important to be in a good section were your classmates are willing to listen to one another and contribute to the discussion.
Yes, especially if interested in global affairs
Yes, if they are interested in getting a broad introduction to global affairs.
If a student wants to gain a brief understanding of current events from around the world, then yes, I would.
Yes, I would. It is a great introduction to global affairs regardless of a students background; I am sure that students of all levels gained a better understanding on the topic throughout the course.
Yes I definitely would. It is extremely interesting and very engaging.

I would recommend this course to everyone. It truly has something for everyone and provides strong background information to help students understand modern global politics and conflicts. Additionally, I would specifically recommend this course to those unsure of what to study. I came into Yale feeling like I loved learning anything, but the variety of topics in this course helped me learn what I am truly interested in.

Somewhatif youre interested in global affairs and want a forum over which to discuss current issues while listening to great speakers, this could be a good introduction. However, the disorganization and odd course structure should give some apprehension.
Only take this course if you are looking for an easy class. It is not very impressive.

If you want a lighter class with lots of interesting, but unrelated, guest speakers, then yes. It is definitely a broad overview of many topics without going in-depth into any of them (except maybe great power competition). Otherwise, pick a more pointed class.
If you want an easy course that is interesting sometimes take this class. otherwise i wouldnt recommend.
I would recommend it to another student if they want to do the major, but besides that, I dont think I would.
Yes
Absolutely. The opportunity to talk about pressing world issues while mingling with top global affairs minds should not be squandered.
Not graded too harshly. I would recommend this course to another student.
I definitely would. It is a very interesting and engaging course!
Absolutely, I believe this class was extremely interesting while also being challenging. These types of classes are exactly why I came to Yale!

I would recommend this course to a student with limited background in Global Affairs who is seeking a survey course. The guest speakers are excellent and I learned about topics I did not know anything about previously. I left the course as a global citizen. However, if a student is looking to study one topic in-depth, this is not the course for them.
Yes, very much so. Incredibly interesting and thought provoking. The idea covered in this class are important and relevant to all people in the entire world.
